Hi Marvin,

Interesting conversation!

On 9/17/06, Marvin Toll <MarvinToll@=
gtcgroup.com> wrote:
>
> In other words, I don't want to "throw out" an OOP=
 inheritance
> solution just because it also includes notating a method wit=
h "test".


Annotations don't hinder your capacity to apply OO principles. =
 Actually,
they give you more flexibility since you are now free to extend =
a class of
your choice, and also to name your methods any way you want.

> =
It is better in this case, because munging your method names sothat a tool
=
> > can pick them off is clearly better addressed with annotations.
>
> MDT=
 ---> Cedric - I do (respectfully) disagree with you on this
> point.  The =
term "optimization for code completion" attempts to
> capture the notion th=
at naming of Classes and Methods can be done in
> a manner that provides mo=
re (immediate) clarity within an IDE
> context.
>
> In an earlier post - yo=
u referred to it as adding "adding metadata
> to that method" name.  In add=
ition to code completion, having all
> like method names begin with a presc=
ribed verb is useful for sorting
> methods.


I agree.  Code completion is =
one of the main reasons why I enforce strictly
the get/set convention throu=
ghout my code and everyone around me.

You are right that currently, code c=
ompletion hasn't been extended to
annotations, so the "test" prefix is more=
 convenient.  I believe it's just a
matter of time before IDE's catch up on=
 that level, though, and as a matter
of fact, Eclipse has been supporting c=
ategories since
3.2<http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops/R-3=
.2-200606291905/new_noteworthy/eclipse-news-part2.html>(JavaDoc
tags you pu=
t on top of your methods, such as "getter" or "setter",
and which you can t=
hen specify in the outline view).

At any rate, just because you start usin=
g annotations doesn't mean you can't
keep starting your test method names w=
ith "test".


> The strength of your conviction in this area is causing me =
to
> wonder.  Am I the only Java "guy" that finds benefit (on a fifteen
> d=
eveloper project on two continents) in having a test method begin
> with he=
 word "test" - or, a callback method begin with "pre"
> or "post" - or, a t=
ransparent persistence registration begin
> with "register"???


No, you're=
 not.  Quite a few TestNG users keep using "test", and that's
fine.

I'm no=
t trying to convince anyone to abandon this idea, but I do want to
make a f=
ew points regarding the adequacy of using annotations in the testing
area, =
because I think they are a perfect tool for this job.

> Following your log=
ic, shouldn't you rename testFoo() to ignoreFoo () then?
> >
>
> Sure.  Exc=
ept for the fact that "test" is a long-term perscription
> and "ignore" is =
(presumably) transitory.  The nuances around which
> capability is appropri=
atly declared and which capability is
> appropriately inherited are more su=
btle than a verb study.
>
> In this case, "ignore" is a contextual assignme=
nt.  It might
> mean, "ignore until I get this test method working".  Where=
as "test"
> means "always test" unless declared otherwise.  "Ignore" is
> (=
conceptual) override of "test".  They are not peers - so, a
> different sty=
listic implementation might be warranted.


Since we're talking stylistic i=
ssues here, I would point out that @Ignore is
a very poor choice for this p=
urpose, since it doesn't say much about "ignore
what?".  Or, in this case, =
"ignored by what?".

The equivalent in TestNG is an attribute:  @Test(enabl=
ed =3D false), which
makes more sense in my opinion.  An even better choice=
 is to put the method
in an ignored group (@Test(groups =3D {"ignored"}) an=
d then exclude that group
from your runs.  The benefit of this approach is =
that the HTML reports list
all the groups that have been included and exclu=
ded, so it's very easy to
get a quick list of all the methods currently bei=
ng ignored.
